rev.comment: /* Cult, NRM, and the sociology and psychology of religion */ Whether the word "cult" applied to NRMs is pejorative when used by secular observers is debated.
/* Cult, NRM, and the sociology and psychology of religion */ What kind of citation is possible here? A reference to a PsycINFO or ERIC search would constitute original research!

/* Cults and NRMs in literature */ unverified POV rm
Sentence contributes nothing to article

/* Societal and governmental pressures on cults */

/* Definitions in [[sociology of religion]] */
/* Study of cults */ Study makes an important contribution to understanding a negative aspect of cult-like behavior.
/* Study of cults */ The anti-cult sphere is not monolithic. If it were, perhaps it would be criticized as cult-like!
/* Study of cults */ The article contains NO REFERENCE to the topic claimed. It does, however, endorse deprogramming ("takes place at a neutral location"), so perhaps a more NPOV article can be found
/* Study of cults */ Deleted POV phrase.
/* Study of cults */ Conway &Siegelman's complete lack of background in psychology is a surprising but important fact.
/* Study of cults */ Broadening the already unweildy category "cult" to include non-religious "cults" is anti-cult POV not accepted by academics. Quotation marks should probably be used throughout.
/* Study of cults */ Wording improvements.
/* Study of cults */ Let's not get into an argument about weak methodological approaches of those whose contribution has been extremely minor anyway.
/* Definitions in [[sociology of religion]] */ grammar
/* Definitions in [[sociology of religion]] */ there is more than one definition
/* Definition in [[sociology of religion]] */ added definition of Roy Wallis

/* Celebrities and Cults */
/* Cults and governments */ Deleted one plainly false statement. It obviously started much earlier.
/* Prevalence of purported cults */ I personally have doubts about whether this method is NPOV, but in any case it is inappropriate to make a defensive editorial comment in an encyclopedia article.
/* Criticism by former members of purported cults */ Minor fixes; call for source.
/* Leaving a cult */ Minor fixes.
/* Leaving a cult */ Reference to death appears to have been vandalism.
/* Leaving a cult */ Commented out long quotation; I've read trained social scientists' assertions that conclusions are based on serious methodological problems. At least contrary statement needed.
/* Leaving a cult */ Each item in this paragraph is supported by specific empirical evidence from a research study conducted by experts, in sharp contrast to partison assertions by anticultists.
/* Leaving a cult */ Anti-cultists complain about deception; they should have edited this paragraph.
/* Leaving a cult */ Commented out self-contradictory statement.
/* Leaving a cult */ Reordered by probably frequency keeping walkaways and castaways together.
/* Leaving a cult */ The former "way #1" was ridiculously narrow and laughably prejudicial: "The Member broke a rule, and was efficiently murdered.'
/* Stigmatization and discrimination */ Rephrased; punctuation.
/* Cults: genuine concerns and exaggerations */ minor grammatical structure/usage
/* Cults: genuine concerns and exaggerations */ I'm not aware that there is empirical research behind this conclusion; if I'm wrong please correct and cite the relevant studies.
/* Cults: genuine concerns and exaggerations */ Added comments; fixed ambiguoug sentences, minor grammar/punctuation/format problems.
/* Development of cults */ Corrected formatting error.

/* Cult, NRM and the sociology and psychology of religion */ Rephrased misleading statements.
/* Study of cults */ rephrased inaccurate POV to attempt a report more in line with reality (more balanced).
correct typo
